citation.article-title: Arsenophonus nasoniae gen. nov., sp. nov., the causative agent of the son-killer trait in the parasitic wasp Nasonia vitripennis.

p.s: Description of Arsenophonus nasoniae sp. nov.
Arsenophonus nasoniae (na. so.' ni. ae. N. L. Nasonia, genus of a fly; nasoniae, of the genus Nasonia.)
The cells are nonmotile, non-spore-forming, long rods, occasionally filamentous in young cultures (0.40 to 0.57 μm wide by 6.9 to 10.0 μm long).
Colonies are mucoid, grey-white, round, and convex with entire edges.
Does not utilize (NH4)2SO4, KNO3, complete defined amino acid mixtures, or acid-hydrolyzed peptones (Casamino Acids) as nitrogen sources.
Enzymatically digested proteins best serve as nitrogen sources.
Utilizes glucose, fructose, and sucrose as primary carbon sources; weak growth is obtained with cellobiose, maltose, trehalose, and D-xylose.
Acid is produced from D-glucose, fructose, and sucrose.
Growth is negative with adonitol, L-arabinose, dulcitol, glycerol, i-inositol, lactose, D-mannitol, and raffinose.
Positive for gelatin liquefaction and catalase.

Negative for nitrate reduction, Voges-Proskauer, methyl red, indole, hydrogen sulfide, oxidase, o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside, arginine dehydrolase, lysine and ornithine decarboxylases, and urease.
Minimum, optimum, and maximum temperatures are 15, 30, and 35°C, respectively.
Cells grow at a pH of 6.2 to 8.7, with an optimum pH range of 7.4 to 8.0.
The G+C content of the DNA is 39.5 mol%.

The type strain is SKI4 (= ATCC 49151), isolated from an N. vitripennis son-killer strain collected near Salt Lake City, Utah. A. nasoniae is the causative agent of the son-killer trait in the parasitic wasp N. vitripennis.
